title: Good Pair Hunting
problem_statement:
Good Pair Hunting

Problem Description

You are given two 1-indexed integer arrays A and B, each of size N, and an integer K. A good pair (i, j) (where 1 <= i < j <= N) satisfies atleast one of the following conditions:

  1. Add K to A[i]. Now let X = A[i] - A[j], Y = B[i] - B[j]. Then X <= Y. Subtract K from A[i] to get back to original A[i].
  2. Add K to B[j]. Now let X = A[i] - A[j], Y = B[i] - B[j]. Then X <= Y. Subtract K from B[j] to get back to original B[j].

Return the number of good pairs.

Input format:

The first line contains two integers N and K.

The second line contains N integers A[1], A[2], ..., A[N].

The third line contains N integers B[1], B[2], ..., B[N].

Output format:

Print the number of good pairs.

Constraints

  • 2 <= N <= 10^5
  • -10^4 <= K <= 10^4
  • -10^4 <= A[i], B[i] <= 10^4

Examples

Example 1:

Input:
4 2
1 2 3 4
5 6 7 8
Output:
6

Explanation: The good pairs are (1, 2), (1, 3), (1, 4), (2, 3), (2, 4), (3, 4).

title: Reduce the Damage
problem_statement:
Reduce the Damage

Problem Description

With the increasing spread of COVID-19, the Government has to isolate the districts. In a network of districts of length lenD, each district i is directly connected to the district j if and only if districts[i][j] == 1, where the length of districts[i] is lenDi. Some districts, k, are in a list start with length lenS have already been infected. If two districts are directly connected, and at least one has the infection, then both the districts will get the virus. The spread will continue in such a manner until it cannot infect any more districts. The total final infected districts, M, has to be reduced. To do this, we should seal one district from start along with its connections to any other district. We should return to the district that minimizes M the most. If we could seal multiple districts, we must return the district with the smallest index.

Input format:

  • First-line consists of two integers, lenD, and lenS.
  • Each of the next lenD lines consists of lenD space-separated integers.
  • Last-line consists of lenS integers.

Output format:

  • Print a single integer denoting the district with the smallest index.

Examples

Example 1:

Input:
3 2
1 1 0
1 1 0
0 0 1
0 1
Output:
0

Explanation: The first row tells us that the length of lenD is 3 and lenS is 2. Now, if we seal 0 from the districts, then we can minimize M to 2. However, the same applies to 1. Thus, as 0 is the smaller index label, we will return it.

Constraints

  • 1 < lenD <= 300 (Note: lenDi in the original text likely refers to lenD)
  • 0 <= districts[i][j] == districts[j][i] <= 1
  • districts[i][i] = 1
  • 1 <= lenS < lenD
  • 0 <= k < lenS

title: Integer to Roman
problem_statement:
Integer to Roman

Problem Description

Roman numerals are represented by seven different symbols: I, V, X, L, C, D and M.

Symbol Value
I 1
V 5
X 10
L 50
C 100
D 500
M 1000

For example, 2 is written as II in Roman numerals, just two one's added together. 12 is written as XII, which is simply X + II. The number 27 is written as XXVII, which is XX + V + II.

Roman numerals are usually written from largest to smallest from left to right. However, the numeral for four is not IIII. Instead, the number four is written as IV. Because the one is before the five we subtract it making four. The same principle applies to the number nine, which is written as IX. There are six instances where subtraction is used:

  • I can be placed before V (5) and X (10) to make 4 and 9.
  • X can be placed before L (50) and C (100) to make 40 and 90.
  • C can be placed before D (500) and M (1000) to make 400 and 900.

Given an integer, convert it to a Roman numeral.

Input Format

The input shall consist of a single line, an N-given integer.

Output Format

Print the Roman numeral of the given integer.

Examples

Example 1:

Input: 58
Output: LVIII

Explanation: In Roman numerals, L represents the number 50, V represents 5, and III represents 3, with each symbol indicating a specific numerical value.

Example 2:

Input: 1994
Output: MCMXCIV

Explanation: In Roman numerals, M represents 1000, CM represents 900 (subtractive notation), XC represents 90 (subtractive notation), and IV represents 4 (subtractive notation). These symbols represent specific numerical values in the Roman numeral system.

Constraints

  • 1 <= N <= 3999
